div1.p: Consulate General of the Independent State of the Congo. Baltimore.
Sir Knight-

It gives me pleasure to announce to you that Mr. Senator Aldrich started to take a special interest in the Congo. During last year he showed himself to be rather benevolent and, from time to time, he performed friendly services for us. Most recently I began the discussion of rubber with him and he was interested in it a lot.

Mr. Aldrich and his son-in-law Rockefeller (son) are the heads of a small but very powerful group taking a great interesst in rubber. Recently they organized a company of 30 million dollar to run the Mexian and South American rubber. Next what they told me is that it's likley that they will want to be interested in the rubber from the Conge in some way.

Mr. Alrich descovered a new manner by which one can, to your advantage, extract some good rubber from the bad herbs or tropical plants that only contain one small part of rubber- that, in effect, only contain ten percent of rubber over 90 for 100 of useless material.

They've made experiments for five years and, finally, they found a method that isn't expensive. They have already worked on Mexican plants and they tell me that they can produce an enormous quanity of four tons a day.
The Senator Aldrich spoke to me about the four tons a day. To work his process in the Congo and I have written to Mr. Major Liebrecht in asking him some exact details on the plants from the Congo.
It's possible that we have a herb or one in the Congo
Sir Knight of the Cuvelier Brussels.
Consulate General of the Independent State of the Congo. Baltimore.
any plant- even a plant that only contains 10 percent of rubber- that respond to the goal.
If one can extract the Congolese herbs from the rubber that up until the present are rested fruitless here a good business for the Congo from the commercial point of view.

In any case- if the process suceeds in the Congo or not- the keen interest from the Senator Aldrich and Mr. Rockefeller in this subject is a good business for the Congo in a political point of view, and it's on this phase of the issue that I want to specially draw your attention.
The Senator Aldrich is very rich, interested in a number of monopolies, and he is very powerful int he Senate. He is "Republican", and is called "The Boss of the Senate".

Rockefeller is, as you know, the very rich sone of Rockefeller form the "Standard Oil Company", and the son-in-law of Mr. Aldrich. He is young, serious- too serious- and a "Baptist qui semble prendre un vif interêt aux affaires religeuses. He was in the ranks of our adversaries, and I can tell you in confidence that, last year, he tried to win the sympathies of Senator Aldrich for the anti-Congolese Baptist missionaries without sucess.

If Senator Aldrich and group want to interest themselves in rubber in the Congo, in any way, the willingness of His Majesty will be very useful for them. Mr. Aldrich knows it well and this fact will not make it less friendly in the Congo.
As for Mr. Rockefeller this fact will give him, maybe, a new perspective and a new manner of thinking.
You will recognize the importance of watching this affaire as confidential for the moment.
I'm writing to Mr. Major Liebrechts today, and, naturally I talked about the subject to Mr. Baron Moncheur also confidetially.
Please accept, Sir Knight, the assurance of my best sentiments.
James Gustavus Whiteley
